trans-unit.source: Access on-premises resources using hybrid connections in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Access on-premises resources using hybrid connections in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Create a connection between a web app in Azure App Service and an on-premises resource that uses a static TCP port
trans-unit.target: Create a connection between a web app in Azure App Service and an on-premises resource that uses a static TCP port

trans-unit.source: You can connect a web app in Azure App Service to any on-premises resource that uses a static TCP port, such as SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, Mobile Services, and most custom Web Services.
trans-unit.target: You can connect a web app in Azure App Service to any on-premises resource that uses a static TCP port, such as SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, Mobile Services, and most custom Web Services.

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to create a hybrid connection between a web app in App Service and an on-premises SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to create a hybrid connection between a web app in App Service and an on-premises SQL Server database.

trans-unit.source: The Web Apps portion of the Hybrid Connections feature is available only in the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The Web Apps portion of the Hybrid Connections feature is available only in the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To create a connection in BizTalk Services, see <linkText>Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To create a connection in BizTalk Services, see <linkText>Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: For a free subscription, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a free subscription, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To use an on-premises SQL Server or SQL Server Express database with a hybrid connection, TCP/IP needs to be enabled on a static port.
trans-unit.target: To use an on-premises SQL Server or SQL Server Express database with a hybrid connection, TCP/IP needs to be enabled on a static port.

trans-unit.source: Using a default instance on SQL Server is recommended because it uses static port 1433.
trans-unit.target: Using a default instance on SQL Server is recommended because it uses static port 1433.

trans-unit.source: For information on installing and configuring SQL Server Express for use with hybrid connections, see <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure web site using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on installing and configuring SQL Server Express for use with hybrid connections, see <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure web site using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The computer on which you install the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager agent described later in this article:
trans-unit.target: The computer on which you install the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager agent described later in this article:

trans-unit.source: Must be able to connect to Azure over port 5671
trans-unit.target: Must be able to connect to Azure over port 5671

trans-unit.source: Must be able to reach the hostname:portnumber of your on-premises resource.
trans-unit.target: Must be able to reach the hostname:portnumber of your on-premises resource.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this article assume that you are using the browser from the computer that will host the on-premises hybrid connection agent.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this article assume that you are using the browser from the computer that will host the on-premises hybrid connection agent.

trans-unit.source: If you have already created a web app in the Azure Portal that you want to use for this tutorial, you can skip ahead to <linkText>Create a Hybrid Connection and a BizTalk Service</linkText><title></title> and start from there.
trans-unit.target: If you have already created a web app in the Azure Portal that you want to use for this tutorial, you can skip ahead to <linkText>Create a Hybrid Connection and a BizTalk Service</linkText><title></title> and start from there.

trans-unit.source: In the lower left corner of the Azure Portal, click New > Web + Mobile > Website.
trans-unit.target: In the lower left corner of the Azure Portal, click New > Web + Mobile > Website.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New button</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New button</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New web app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New web app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Web app blade, provide a URL > Create.
trans-unit.target: On the Web app blade, provide a URL > Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Website name</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Website name</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After a few moments, the web app is created and its web app blade appears.
trans-unit.target: After a few moments, the web app is created and its web app blade appears.

trans-unit.source: The blade is a vertically scrollable dashboard that lets you manage your site.
trans-unit.target: The blade is a vertically scrollable dashboard that lets you manage your site.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Website running</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Website running</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To verify the site is live, you can click the Browse icon to display the default page.
trans-unit.target: To verify the site is live, you can click the Browse icon to display the default page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click browse to see your web app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click browse to see your web app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Default web app page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Default web app page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Next, you will create a hybrid connection and a BizTalk service for the web app.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will create a hybrid connection and a BizTalk service for the web app.

trans-unit.source: Scroll down the blade for your web app and choose Hybrid connections.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down the blade for your web app and choose Hybrid connections.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Hybrid connections</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hybrid connections</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Hybrid connections blade, click Add.
trans-unit.target: On the Hybrid connections blade, click Add.

trans-unit.source: The Add a hybrid connection blade opens.
trans-unit.target: The Add a hybrid connection blade opens.

trans-unit.source: Since this is your first hybrid connection, the New hybrid connection option is preselected, and the Create hybrid connection blade opens for you.
trans-unit.target: Since this is your first hybrid connection, the New hybrid connection option is preselected, and the Create hybrid connection blade opens for you.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a hybrid connection</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a hybrid connection</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Create hybrid connection blade:
trans-unit.target: On the Create hybrid connection blade:

trans-unit.source: For Name, provide a name for the connection.
trans-unit.target: For Name, provide a name for the connection.

trans-unit.source: For Hostname, enter the name of the on-premises computer that hosts your resource.
trans-unit.target: For Hostname, enter the name of the on-premises computer that hosts your resource.

trans-unit.source: For Port, enter the port number that your on-premises resource uses (1433 for a SQL Server default instance).
trans-unit.target: For Port, enter the port number that your on-premises resource uses (1433 for a SQL Server default instance).

trans-unit.source: Click Biz Talk Service
trans-unit.target: Click Biz Talk Service

trans-unit.source: The Create BizTalk Service blade opens.
trans-unit.target: The Create BizTalk Service blade opens.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the BizTalk service, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the BizTalk service, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create BizTalk service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create BizTalk service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Create BizTalk Service blade closes and you are returned to the Create hybrid connection blade.
trans-unit.target: The Create BizTalk Service blade closes and you are returned to the Create hybrid connection blade.

trans-unit.source: On the Create hybrid connection blade, click OK.
trans-unit.target: On the Create hybrid connection blade, click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click OK</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click OK</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the process completes, the notifications area in the portal informs you that the connection has been successfully created.
trans-unit.target: When the process completes, the notifications area in the portal informs you that the connection has been successfully created.

trans-unit.source: On the web app's blade, the Hybrid connections icon now shows that 1 hybrid connection has been created.
trans-unit.target: On the web app's blade, the Hybrid connections icon now shows that 1 hybrid connection has been created.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>One hybrid connection created</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>One hybrid connection created</linkText>

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have completed an important part of the cloud hybrid connection infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have completed an important part of the cloud hybrid connection infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will create a corresponding on-premises piece.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will create a corresponding on-premises piece.

trans-unit.source: On the web app's blade, click the Hybrid connections icon.
trans-unit.target: On the web app's blade, click the Hybrid connections icon.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Hybrid connections icon</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hybrid connections icon</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Hybrid connections blade, the Status column for the recently added endpoint shows Not connected.
trans-unit.target: On the Hybrid connections blade, the Status column for the recently added endpoint shows Not connected.

trans-unit.source: Click the connection to configure it.
trans-unit.target: Click the connection to configure it.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Not connected</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Not connected</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Hybrid connection blade opens.
trans-unit.target: The Hybrid connection blade opens.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>NotConnectedBlade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>NotConnectedBlade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the blade, click Listener Setup.
trans-unit.target: On the blade, click Listener Setup.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click Listener Setup</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click Listener Setup</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Hybrid connection properties blade opens.
trans-unit.target: The Hybrid connection properties blade opens.

trans-unit.source: Under On-premises Hybrid Connection Manager, choose Click here to install.
trans-unit.target: Under On-premises Hybrid Connection Manager, choose Click here to install.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click here to install</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click here to install</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Application Run security warning dialog, choose Run to continue.
trans-unit.target: In the Application Run security warning dialog, choose Run to continue.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Choose Run to continue</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Choose Run to continue</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the User Account Control dialog, choose Yes.
trans-unit.target: In the User Account Control dialog, choose Yes.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Choose Yes</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Choose Yes</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Hybrid Connection Manager is downloaded and installed for you.
trans-unit.target: The Hybrid Connection Manager is downloaded and installed for you.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Installing</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Installing</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the install completes, click Close.
trans-unit.target: When the install completes, click Close.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click Close</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click Close</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Hybrid connections blade, the Status column now shows Connected.
trans-unit.target: On the Hybrid connections blade, the Status column now shows Connected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connected Status</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connected Status</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now that the hybrid connection infrastructure is complete, you can create a hybrid application that uses it.
trans-unit.target: Now that the hybrid connection infrastructure is complete, you can create a hybrid application that uses it.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: For information on creating an ASP.NET web application that uses a hybrid connection, see <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure web site using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on creating an ASP.NET web application that uses a hybrid connection, see <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure web site using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For information on using a hybrid connection with a mobile service, see <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure mobile service using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on using a hybrid connection with a mobile service, see <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure mobile service using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hybrid Connections overview</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <linkText>Reference on Websites and Web Apps in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <linkText>Reference on Websites and Web Apps in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>
